expanded_description: Not all systems of equations are the same. Some have exactly one solution, some have none, and some have infinitely many. Classifying systems helps us understand what kind of solution to expect before we even begin solving, and it provides insight into the relationship between the equations. The terminology—consistent, inconsistent, independent, dependent—is essential for communicating about systems.

core_concept.principle:
Systems of linear equations can be classified by their number of solutions:
• **Consistent and independent**: Exactly one solution (lines intersect at one point)
• **Inconsistent**: No solution (lines are parallel)
• **Consistent and dependent**: Infinitely many solutions (lines are coincident)
The type can be determined by comparing slopes and intercepts without graphing.
core_concept.explanation: Think of classification like labeling animals. 'Consistent' means the system has at least one solution (like animals that exist). 'Inconsistent' means no solution (like mythical creatures). Among consistent systems, 'independent' means exactly one solution (like a unique animal), while 'dependent' means infinitely many (like a species with many individuals).

sections.introduction: Every system of two linear equations falls into one of three categories based on how the lines relate to each other.

key_concept.definition:
• **Consistent and Independent**: The lines intersect at exactly one point. There is one unique solution.
• **Inconsistent**: The lines are parallel and never intersect. There is no solution.
• **Consistent and Dependent**: The lines are coincident (the same line). There are infinitely many solutions.
key_concept.context: These classifications describe the relationship between the equations and tell us what to expect when solving.

classifications.behavior: The system has exactly one solution.

examples.explanation: Slopes 2 and -1 (different) → intersect at one point
Same slope 3, different intercepts → parallel, no solution

classifications.behavior: Every point on the line is a solution.

worked_examples.problem: For each graph, classify the system as consistent independent, inconsistent, or consistent dependent.

step_by_step.explanation: Only one line visible—they are coincident

worked_examples.final_answer: A: Consistent independent, B: Inconsistent, C: Consistent dependent

sections.introduction: We can determine the type of system without graphing by comparing the slopes and y-intercepts of the equations.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.2.9: Using slopes and intercepts to classify.

key_concept.definition:
For two linear equations in slope-intercept form $y = m_1x + b_1$ and $y = m_2x + b_2$:
• If $m_1 \neq m_2$: different slopes → lines intersect → consistent independent
• If $m_1 = m_2$ and $b_1 \neq b_2$: same slope, different intercepts → parallel → inconsistent
• If $m_1 = m_2$ and $b_1 = b_2$: same slope and intercept → same line → consistent dependent
key_concept.context: This method works even when equations are in different forms—just convert to slope-intercept form first.

worked_examples.title: Classifying by Slope and Intercept
worked_examples.problem:
Classify each system as consistent independent, inconsistent, or consistent dependent:
a) $\begin{cases} y = 2x + 3 \\ y = 2x - 1 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} y = 3x - 2 \\ y = -x + 4 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} y = \frac{1}{2}x + 2 \\ 2y = x + 4 \end{cases}$
d) $\begin{cases} y = 4x + 1 \\ y = 4x + 1 \end{cases}$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Inconsistent, b) Consistent independent, c) Consistent dependent, d) Consistent dependent
worked_examples.concept_applied: Compare slopes and intercepts to determine the type of system.

image.alt: Summary of classifying by slope and intercept
image.caption: Figure 7.2.12: Slope-intercept classification summary.

sections.introduction: When equations are in standard form $Ax + By = C$, we can still classify them without converting to slope-intercept form.

key_concept.definition:
For a system $\begin{cases} A_1x + B_1y = C_1 \\ A_2x + B_2y = C_2 \end{cases}$:
• If $\frac{A_1}{A_2} = \frac{B_1}{B_2} \neq \frac{C_1}{C_2}$, the lines are parallel → inconsistent
• If $\frac{A_1}{A_2} = \frac{B_1}{B_2} = \frac{C_1}{C_2}$, the lines are coincident → consistent dependent
• If $\frac{A_1}{A_2} \neq \frac{B_1}{B_2}$, the lines intersect → consistent independent
key_concept.context: This method uses the ratios of coefficients to determine the relationship between lines.

worked_examples.title: Classifying from Standard Form
worked_examples.problem:
Classify each system using ratio comparisons:
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 12 \\ 4x + 6y = 24 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 8 \\ 6x - 4y = 10 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} 2x + 5y = 10 \\ 3x - 2y = 7 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.calculation: A/B ratios equal, but C ratio different → inconsistent

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Consistent dependent, b) Inconsistent, c) Consistent independent
worked_examples.concept_applied: Compare the ratios of coefficients and constants to classify standard form systems.

sections.introduction: Some systems require careful attention, especially when equations appear different but are actually equivalent.

introduction_image.alt: Equations that look different but are the same
introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.2.17: Special cases in classification.

key_concept.definition:
Be aware of:
• Equations that are multiples of each other (dependent)
• Equations with the same slope but different intercepts (inconsistent)
• Equations that need simplification before classification
• Vertical and horizontal lines (special slope cases)
key_concept.context: Always simplify equations to their simplest form before classifying.

worked_examples.title: Handling Special Cases
worked_examples.problem:
Classify each system:
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 6 \\ 4x + 6y = 12 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} y = 3x - 2 \\ 6x - 2y = 4 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} x = 4 \\ y = -2 \end{cases}$
d) $\begin{cases} y = 2x + 5 \\ y = 2x + 5 \end{cases}$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Consistent dependent, b) Consistent dependent, c) Consistent independent, d) Consistent dependent
worked_examples.concept_applied: Always simplify equations before classifying. Vertical and horizontal lines are special but follow the same rules.

sections.introduction: The classification of a system has real-world meaning. Different types correspond to different practical situations.

introduction_image.alt: Real-world scenarios for each system type
introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.2.21: Real-world classification meanings.

key_concept.definition:
• **Consistent independent** (one solution): Two conditions that determine a unique outcome—like finding the price of two items given two total costs.
• **Inconsistent** (no solution): Impossible conditions—like requiring a person to be both under 18 and over 65 simultaneously.
• **Consistent dependent** (infinite solutions): Redundant conditions—like having two different equations that say the same thing.
key_concept.context: Understanding the type helps interpret what the system means in a real-world context.

image.alt: Examples: unique prices, impossible requirements, redundant information
image.caption: Figure 7.2.22: Real-world examples.

worked_examples.title: Interpreting Real-World Systems
worked_examples.problem:
For each situation, determine whether the system would be consistent independent, inconsistent, or consistent dependent. Explain what this means in context.
a) Two equations relating the prices of apples and bananas from two different purchases.
b) Two equations that both say 'x + y = 10' but written differently.
c) Requirements that a number must be both greater than 5 and less than 3.

step_by_step.explanation: Different combinations typically give different equations that intersect at a unique price point
step_by_step.calculation: Consistent independent—there is a unique price for each fruit

step_by_step.explanation: Both equations say the same thing
step_by_step.calculation: Consistent dependent—any combination summing to 10 works, no unique answer

step_by_step.explanation: No number can be both >5 and <3

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) Consistent independent (unique prices)
b) Consistent dependent (redundant information)
c) Inconsistent (impossible requirements)
worked_examples.concept_applied: System classification has direct real-world interpretations.

sections.section_title: 7.2.6 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when classifying systems. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Mixing up no solution and infinite solutions.
characteristics: Thinking parallel lines have infinite solutions
Thinking same line has no solution

image.caption: Figure 7.2.25: Error - confusing inconsistent and dependent.

examples.process: Error: Saying parallel lines have infinitely many solutions
examples.explanation: Correct: Parallel lines have no solution; coincident lines have infinite solutions

classifications.value: Classifying without putting equations in simplest form.

examples.process: Error: Saying $2x + 4y = 8$ and $x + 2y = 4$ are different lines
examples.explanation: Correct: Second multiplied by 2 gives first → same line

classifications.value: Using ratio method incorrectly, especially with signs.

examples.process: Error: For $2x - 3y = 6$ and $4x - 6y = 12$, saying ratios are different

worked_examples.title: Correcting Classification Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student classified the system $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 8 \\ 6x - 4y = 16 \end{cases}$ as inconsistent. Identify and correct the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Second equation is just 2 times the first

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct: Consistent dependent. Student missed that the equations are equivalent.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Always check if one equation is a multiple of another.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to classify a variety of systems.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Classify each system as consistent independent, inconsistent, or consistent dependent:
1) $\begin{cases} y = 2x + 5 \\ y = 2x - 3 \end{cases}$
2) $\begin{cases} y = 3x - 1 \\ y = -2x + 4 \end{cases}$
3) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 12 \\ 4x + 6y = 24 \end{cases}$
4) $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 6 \\ 6x - 4y = 10 \end{cases}$
5) $\begin{cases} x = 5 \\ y = 2x - 3 \end{cases}$
6) $\begin{cases} y = \frac{1}{2}x + 3 \\ 2y = x + 6 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.calculation: They intersect at one point → consistent independent

summary: Systems of linear equations can be classified into three types based on their solutions. A consistent and independent system has exactly one solution, occurring when lines have different slopes and intersect at a single point. An inconsistent system has no solution, occurring when lines are parallel (same slope, different intercepts). A consistent and dependent system has infinitely many solutions, occurring when lines are coincident (same slope and intercept—the same line). To classify without graphing, compare slopes and intercepts when equations are in slope-intercept form. For equations in standard form $Ax + By = C$, compare the ratios $\frac{A_1}{A_2}$, $\frac{B_1}{B_2}$, and $\frac{C_1}{C_2}$. If all ratios are equal, the system is dependent. If $\frac{A_1}{A_2} = \frac{B_1}{B_2} \neq \frac{C_1}{C_2}$, the system is inconsistent. If $\frac{A_1}{A_2} \neq \frac{B_1}{B_2}$, the system is independent. Real-world interpretations: independent systems give unique solutions (e.g., specific prices), inconsistent systems represent impossible conditions, and dependent systems represent redundant information. Understanding these classifications helps in choosing solution methods and interpreting results.
